comments.commentBody:
I despise Uber and Lyft and other such ride-sharing services and never use them. Despite the personal financial advantage they offer, I refuse to use them because their business model is nothing more than patent exploitation masquerading as some sort of progressive "new economy" industry.

Uber lines its pockets with the labor of drivers who are desperate to make ends meet and are thus willing to use their own capital investment (their cars) and pay for the costs of maintaining those capital investments, while getting subpar wages and receiving no benefits or labor protections from Uber.

Hypocritical upper middle class liberals talk the I-hate-Uber talk but won't walk the walk because -- in contrast to when they're at home watching Bill Mahr on TV -- when they're on the street their self-interest easily outweighs their politics.

Transportation is regulated by local, state and federal government for myriad reasons related to safety and efficient use of pubic resources. The fact that the project of regulating transportation services is not well executed by government, or that profit margins in the taxi business in any particular locale do not permit the provision of service as comfortable as that offered by Uber is not, in my view, a reason to embrace Uber's exploitation.

Put another way, if we legalized slavery for purposes of the taxi business, I'm sure I could provide taxi service that would be half the cost of Uber's and twice as nice in amenities.

My 65 year old brother's life was ruined by Uber. 40 years ago he purchased a medallion in Boston, risked his life driving for years, paid the City annual fees, bought an expensive Prius the City required, and followed the City's other expensive rules and regulations. He accepted the lower pays thinking he'd sell the medallion to retire. That medallion is valueless now as Uber is allowed to provide basically the same service without complying with these rules. The taxi license only applies to the little guy. The small business owner.

How can it be legal that a government that required some to pay for licenses now allows others to perform basically the same function without regulatlons? Decent law abiding people's life savings have been destroyed by Kalinak and politicians without fair compensation for the "taking" of their businesses. In the place of decent jobs, Kalinak has created fragmented, poor-paying part time gigs without benefits.

This is the slippery slope created over the years by the destruction of unions and good paying jobs. The new "gig" economy benefits the few who "create" the business, invest in the stock market or are in political office.

The only surprise in all this is that Kalinak quit Trump's commission. i remain convinced he found a soul mate in a man with an equally deplorable personal and professional reputation who flaunts the law and bullies others.
Necco wafers are still around: https://www.walmart.com/ip/Necco-The-Original-Candy-Wafer-Rolls-24-count...

Vouchers create two serious problems.  First, money is diverted from public schools which badly need funds.  Second, the Establishment clause of the First Amendment is violated by sponsoring and funding religion.

Somehow, the Chinese and the Russiwns have to be brought on board allowing us to take out this entire regime and its missile systems before they can level Seoul, which the North is clearly poised and ready to do. I do not know if anyone in Washington picking up after the current Trump carnage has the ability, integrity or backing necessary to put such a strategy in place.

Why do people keep thinking of nuclear weapons as if the only way to use them is to blow up things to pieces? A nuclear weapon doesn't even have to hit ground to have a devastating effect. The real danger for this electronically dependent world we live in is the crippling effects of a powerful EMP. Anyone who understands this reality and is thinking NK and Iran are ignorant of this, is incredibly stupid. "One Second After" explains it in the most gut retching way.

I guess you didn't read the article. Obama and the US military did take actions to slow the development of the North Korean nuclear missile program. The point the article makes however is that there are limited options short of a preemptive risky US military strike or invasion that could stop the North Korean progress to reach their goal . Such a military action would probably cause retaliation by China who by the way do have lots of nuclear ICBM's that would strike the US and as the article points out the US anti missile system costing $300 BILLION will not protect us.
Trump is inheriting this situation and will now learn that boastful statements like "it won't happen" and idle threats of military strikes you suggest should be employed are silly, harmful and don't do anything to manage or solve the problem.
I am waiting for a twit describing the specifications of the program and how he himself built this stupendous greatest ever built system. :)
I understand that now Trump is tweeting that he was wire tapped by Obama. I mean, really. This guy is paranoid. With him in charge, problems with North Korea or anybody else will be maximized.

The launching facilities are moveable. With the missiles.  We would have to warn China first (secretly of course, but, would they tell NK or not?). If they have any immobile launching facilities I bet they are within miles of China.

Countless hours have been spent by countless brilliant experts running countless computer simulations trying to come up with a plan that would work to neuter North Korea. The fact that we're still watching Kim Jong Un march basically unimpeded to his goal of ICBM capability should tell everyone that there are no good solutions to the problem, or at least, none that work without the full cooperation of China.

Unfortunately, China does not want North Korea and South Korea to unite, because that would fairly quickly mean a democratic and powerful Korea directly on China's border. And we are quickly getting to the point -- once North Korea has enough nuclear warheads to obliterate a large swath of China -- when even China won't be able to push North Korea in the right direction.

So the world is left with an insoluble problem. Oh, wait . . . I forgot about Donald Trump! He's smarter than all the generals, and he has a secret plan to defeat ISIS, so he must also have a secret plan to defeat North Korea, right?

Oh, never mind.

If you think China has much leverage here you might want to buy a bridge in NYC.  They are concerned with a massive influx of people from North Korea more than anything else.  The only solution would be a revolution in North Korea and unless the military revolts that won't be happening either.  Crazy dictators are only stopped by force and that includes killing them.

Even if true, Trump’s latest accusation against President Obama doesn’t bother me in the slightest. The telephone lines of all known political nutcases ought to be monitored by our government 24 hours a day for reasons of public safety; so if President Trump’s phones aren’t already being tapped, somebody should begin doing it today.

First of all, forget about Stuxnet. It's either a hoax or a very stupid stunt. It could only have worked if the North Koreans were foolish enough to allow some connection between their computers and the rest of the world and I'm sure they aren't. Believe it or not, not everything is connected to the Internet.

But No. Korea's nukes and rockets are real and a very serious threat. And with Trump in control of our nukes, he is himself as grave a threat to us all as No. Korea. Kim Jung un has maybe 10, nukes, Trump controls thousands.

You admit, without saying it, that there will always be war. Are conventional weapons so much safer? Send a B-1 Bomber over the Kremlin full of HE & Thermo conventional weapons & there will still be a fire storm. If you kill all the people in an area, does it really matter if it is done with conventional explosives or nukes? Not to them I think. Your scenario is only going to come to pass if a small country (N.Korea) launches one or 5 small nukes at us, that China, Russia, Vietnam will all launch at us right then too. When I think China & Russia will be more pragmatic & if they launch at all, it will be at N.Korea with more deadliness than we will. They don't want world destruction. They don't want their own destruction. Our allies will launch at them if they launch at us. N.Korea if they launch will be risking total destruction by their allies. Dear leader doesn't care about his people, but, he wants to live. With his so called allies standing ready to add to his destruction he will lose that option. They know where his secret hiding places are. Even if we miss one or two. Other countries with nukes (like India & Pakistan) will not fire their hard won nukes on anyone but each other. They won't do that if all the missiles are heading in other directions.

You wait until North Korea has one of their many obsequiously staged military parades with the leadership all gathered, and fire off a dozen stealth cruise missiles and obliterate them. End of problem.

comments.userLocation: Deep in the heart of Texas
comments.commentBody: @Luomaike, you wrote "Trump is The Great Dealmaker...." This is more wishful thinking from those who believe/hope Trump will someday start acting like a normal president. There is no evidence that Trump is great at anything worthwhile. But there is considerable evidence that he is a terrible deal maker and businessman, er, con man. The rest of the world and most of our nation already know this. The only reason China would want to make a "deal" with Trump is to take advantage of his lousy deal-making skills to stick it to us. Please explain how I might be wrong.
Thats contrary what trump is doing with closing car productions in mexico lovering there economy.  america first,  does not care about other countries as far i saw.

As distasteful as Trump is, he has a real opportunity to do something about NK. I came in the Navy as an ensign in 1986 and over the course of a 26 career saw little real change in the standoff/stalemate with NK. Despite the massive investments the U.S. made to neutralize the threat (we spent nearly $1B on a single mobile missile defense ship that is being mothballed, eg), NK has managed to stay level with us though having no where near the level of resources we do....just by making threats.

Trump--for obvious reasons--has the opportunity to shun convention and take a radically different approach. Not sure what that will be but wouldn't surprise me if he baits NK into doing something that elicits an overwhelming, multi-lateral kinetic response. In then end I think if you make it clear to NK that you are willing to "take their best shot"--and that life as they know it will end for good shortly thereafter--they will cave. But you gotta be willing to take a punch...something no administration has seriously considered in my lifetime. Not saying there's not significant risk there...NK could actually land at least a glancing blow if they get lucky. But a novel--gasp--"Trumpian" approach may be what it takes to finally wipe that smile off Mr. Kim's face.

If President Trump thinks North Korea is the greatest threat to American security he might like to google "Foundations of Geopolitics" and reflect on the Russian long term game plan set out in that document.

Then: "Bin Laden Determined to Strike in U.S.”  Warnings ignored. Bush administration focused on Russia. Now: North Korean threat is Trump's biggest challenge. While Trump rants on Twitter and gets more paranoid and Nixon-like by the minute, Russia looms large once again as a major distraction to the new administration. There is good reason to fear for our very survival.

i hope sincerely that this article isn't one of the starts in an attempt to garner fear of another boogieman on the face of the world.  well now that our president embraces the ex  soviet union with glee i guess north korea is the new fear to fear.  this gets tiresome after all these decades.
Agreed. Reading this in a national forum has been enlightening but also, terrifying, given the current administration.

We do need to get rid of our wanna be "dear leader". But, bowing to N.Korea & letting him keep advancing in nuclear capability is not the answer. Dictators do respond to the threat of THEM being obliterated. Their slaves not so much. Being cowards in the face of the enemy is never a good idea. Particularly when the enemy is insane. Doing that is the same as egging them on. That is also why just 'giving in" & ignoring *45 is a bad idea. He must be stopped. He is our problem. Getting rid of him will go a good way to easing tensions between us and the world (including N.Korea).

Let's hope the Trump "team" is reading this - it seems to be a veiled educational lesson for them - as they are so inept and inexperienced and get most of their info from the press.  Nice job, Times.  Let's hope it works or we're all in deep trouble.
